awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Wideband Multi-Beam Antenna Arrays: Low-Complexity Algorithms and Analog-CMOS Implementations
awd_abstract_narration:
The Federal Communications Commission recognizes the need for the wireless industry to explore the 28-95 GHz millimeter-wave (mm-wave) bands where wider bandwidth is available, and future allocations may reach above 100 GHz. This explosion of mm-wave bandwidth opens up applications in 5G wireless systems spanning communications, localization, imaging, and radar. This project addresses fundamental scientific and engineering challenges in generating multiple parallel radio "beams" at mm-wave frequencies. A radio beam refers to a directional channel that establishes point-to-point contact for wireless communications and remote sensing. The ability to form a large number of such radio beams with high bandwidths will tremendously improve the performance for next-generation wireless systems. For example, multiple beams are essential for achieving the orders-of-magnitude increases in capacity, data rate, and geographical penetration required by the explosive growth in wireless applications. Moreover, they are important for both transmitters and receivers.  The project will draw on an analogy between the spatial Fourier transform and a thin optical lens to obtain multiple wideband beams. Unlike lens-antenna-based approaches in the literature, this project will use a planar aperture antenna in conjunction with analog integrated circuits to generate many wideband mm-wave beams subject to power and size constraints. The proposed highly integrated approach is attractive for mobile applications including 5G smart devices, the internet of things, mobile robotics, and unmanned aerial vehicles, and other emerging applications focused on mm-waves. In addition to scientific research, the project will ensure that both minority students and female students will be mentored towards careers in mathematics, communications, as well as microwave circuits and systems. Educational materials will be developed for teaching array signal processing, microwave integrated circuit (IC) design, and ultra-high-speed analog signal processing. Principal Investigators (PIs) Madanayake and Mandal will organize a mini-conference to enhance microwave and mm-wave research activities at nearby universities in northeast Ohio. PI Madanayake will collaborate with co-PIs towards mentoring underrepresented students towards careers in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM).  The proposal team is uniquely placed to promote STEM topics spanning both electrical engineering and mathematics domains. The project will lead to education of the wider community on the importance of cross-disciplinary collaboration. Further, the team will strive to show the importance of learning deeper math topics towards success in technology and engineering careers.


A multi-beam array receiver is deeply difficult to realize in IC form due to the underlying complexity of its signal flow graph. In this work, mathematical methods based on the theories of i) sparse factorization of structured complex matrices, and ii) approximate transforms are proposed to solve this problem. The resulting matrices are realized with multi-GHz bandwidths using analog ICs. One of the intellectual contributions is the development of efficient wideband beamformers based on sparse factorizations of delay Vandermonde matrices (DVM). This DVM algorithm solves the longstanding "beam squint" problem, i.e., the fact that the beam direction changes with input frequency, making true wideband operation impossible. Another is the derivation of transform matrices with specified properties that approximate the discrete Fourier transform (DFT). Such approximate transforms are not subjected to the known computational complexity bounds of the exact DFT, and approximate-DFT-based multi-beamformers can in fact be efficiently implemented using current-mode analog ICs. Finally, precision circuit design, digital calibration, built-in self-test, and other methods will be explored for efficiently realizing the proposed multi-beamforming networks in analog IC form.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the topic of wideband multi-beam beamforming using true-time-delay (TTD) techniques. A beamformer is a system that directionally enhances a propagating electromagnetic plane-wave based on the desired direction of arrival (DOA). A TTD beamformer is a special case of beamformers where the signals are coherently summed to constructively interfere along the desired DOA while destructively interfering along undesired directions. From array signal processing theory, TTD are known as optimum beamformers for enhancing plane-wave signals that have been corrupted by wide sense stationary (WSS) additive white gaussian noise (AWGN). An N-element array requires N units of TTD elements to create a beamformer. For N independent beams, that is an N-beam multi-beam beamformer, the number of TTDs is typically N^2. From linear algebra theory, the N-beam beamforming operation takes takes a matrix vector form via Delay Vandemonde Matrix (DVM). This research was successful in reducing the number of TTDs from O(N^2) to O(N log N) via sparse factorization of the DVM matrix into a product of sparse matrices consisting of TTD based circuit elements. It was discovered that both analog-RF and digital realization of the low-complexity DVM factorizations were possible, in turn leading to a range of new low-complexity FFT-like fast algorithms for DVM matrix, having low-complexity being proposed and mapped to analog integrated circuit (IC) architectures.

 

Furthermore, the project also explored the use of approximate computing for reducing the circuit complexity of multi-beam beamformers via the application of approximate-FFT algorithms with array processing. The analog multi-beam architectures are based on wideband all-pass filters (APFs) realized using analog RF-CMOS circuits. The digital multi-beam architectures are based on wideband fractional delay interpolation filters that can be realized on both single-phase and multi-rate (i.e., polyphase) digital signal processing systems. A suite of low-complexity algorithms are prototype realizations were explored, prototyped and evaluated leading to a range of mathematical, circuits, and systems based peer reviewed scientific publications.

Wideband multi-beam beamformers are a crucial requirement for scientific instrumentation such as radio telescope arrays, search for extra-terrestrial intelligence, study of the earth’s ionosphere, space science, wireless communications including 5G/6G systems, radar systems, and electronic warfare systems based on radio frequency (RF) sensing. The project focused on this crucial capability for observing radio phenomena across multiple directions at the same time, and across a very wide range of the spectrum, at greatly reduced system complexity. The reduction of number of TTD elements from about N^2 down to about N log N number of units greatly reduces the hardware complexity of the underlying instrumentation, in turn leading to lowered costs for large scale instrumentation, smaller size and weight, and proportionately reduced power consumption. The project lead to training of several doctoral students, including under-represented students at Florida International University (FIU) which is a Carnegie R1 Research institution, and at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (ERAU) which has a world-leading aerospace programs. The project led to multiple opportunities for training America’s workforce and to help the nation wide drive for electronics resurgence as evidenced by the CHIPS act. PhD level scientists who graduated with NSF support have since joined US tech industry related to chip design, semiconductors, and wireless communications.

The PIs believe high-tech innovation from this project is a key part of economic development which has been well facilitated with NSF support. The project also led to multiple scientific outreach activities, including peer reviewed papers, academic meetings, industrial conferences, and invited seminars open to the public. Broader impacts include conferences for female scientists and students, student meetings, and seminars/demonstrations in multiple venues including the Brooklyn 5G Summit. The research findings of this project enables future activities for wireless industry, defense industry, and radio science community in terms of high-performance instrumentation at low power and complexity.
